poem:
**Reading Peckinpah at Dawn**

The paper proclaims him,  
nihilistic and anarchic,  
a lore of dust and desert  
inked in red and rum.

I sip my coffee,  
watch the light slip  
through slanted blinds,  
imagine gunfights in the hall.

Charlton leads the charge,  
scripts rewritten with smoke,  
the morning settling like  
cigarette ash in the air.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Nihilistic, anarchic, repugnant: Sam Peckinpah’s 10 best films – ranked! 10. Major Dundee (1965) After making his name as a director of westerns, Sam Peckinpah was given his first shot at making a major studio film – an epic about a tyrannical cavalry officer (Charlton Heston) leading an expedition into Mexico. The production set a template for later Peckinpah films – heavy drinking, personality clashes, battles with the suits, and a final cut not matching". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
